content.description: Marked out in red. The route starts on the lake-facing side of Crackhead. Find the US, a descent jug to match your hands on, then traverse left, where, in order to get to the side the picture presents, your must use a heel hook and a side pull on the pictured side. Pull yourself up on your heel, and get your hands into the crack heading slightly down, towards the ground on your left. Traverse until the end of the crack, where you should use a side pull/crimp in order to reach a jug hold, from which the climb directly up crackhead should be relatively easy. Top out.

Marked out in yellow. Starting on the US, a jug around the corner on the lake-facing side of Crackhead, traverse slightly left and use a heel hook and a side pull in order to get yourself over to the pictured side of Crackhead. Pull yourself upright, and get your hands in the crack heading slightly downwards towards the ground. From there, get your right foot into the horizontal crack system next to/in front of you and reach for a good but small semi-crimp ~3 ft above you. Once held, traverse towards your left on Crackhead and continue until you cannot move any farther left.

 This route can be particularly wet after a rainstorm, so I would advise leaving at least 2 dry days between an attempt and poor weather.

This rock owes its name to its head-like shape and two prominent cracks running down the main climbing side of it. Take care after a rainy day, as this boulder's route can be quite wet afterwards.

 US = Universal Start, where both routes on this boulder start. It is a jug on the lake-facing side of the lake.
